results.title: De Munich a la Drole de Guerre (1938-1939) Pt. 06
results.brief_description:
Part 6 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. At the end of the tumultuous 1930s, French cinema produces the full range of film genre: film noir, film rose, comedies. During the decade, Renoir and Carne will produce their best work. Julien Duvivier directs ‘Carnet de bal’, followed by ‘La fin du jour’ and ‘La charette fantome’. Some directors experience difficulties to impose subjects which are not pure entertainement. Nevertheless, Marc Allegret is allowed to to do ‘Razumoff’, a film dealing with Russian revolutionaries. In ‘Gribouille’, Allegret casts a promising young actress, Michele Morgan. During this decade, a long list of young actors are given their first chance to appear in the big screen. Some of them will go on to become iconic figures of French cinema for fourty years and more. Young hopefuls such as Claude Dauphin, Bernard Blier, Odette Joyeux play young hopeful actors auditioning for the ‘Conservatoire’ in front of Louis Jouvet, playing himself in ‘Entree des artistes’. Jean Gremillon, with the support of Raoul Ploquin, is filming ‘L’etrange Mr. Victor’ in Berlin for the French section of UFA. Based in Paris, G.W. Pabst directs ‘Le drame de Shanghai’ and ‘Damsel in distress’. During the last years of the 1930s Pagnol directs ‘Regain’ and ‘La femme du boulanger’. Theatre man Sacha Guitry learns the craft of filmmaking and makes a specialty of adapting his plays and creating historical dramas with 1000s of cameo apparitions. In spite of many attempts to resurface, pioneers such as Gance and L’Herbier are not able to renew with box-office success. A lesser known figure of the period is Pierre Chenal. He made a German expressionist-style Dostoyevsky adaptation, ‘Crime and Punishment’ (1935) in which he used set design, lighting, a breathtakingly mobile camera, and voice-over monologues to evoke a tormented consciousness at the breaking point. In adapting James M. Cain’s ‘The postman alway rings twice’ as ‘Le dernier tournant’ (1939), he shot extensively on location, in another French adumbration (along with Renoir’s ‘Toni’ (1934) and most of Pagnol’s work) of postwar Neorealism. In ‘L’alibi’ (1938), which stylistically and thematically is the closest of his films to the work of Carne and Prevert, he all but abandoned his usual moving camera, while multiplying (studio shot) expressionistic effects of lighting and composition.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992. * Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Interviewees include: Yves Allegret, Marc Allegret, Charles Spaak, Marcel Pagnol, Francoise Giroud, Henri-George Clouzot.

results.title: Our Policemen
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The film aims to further an appreciation in children of the work of the police - not only as custodians of the law but also as friendly helpers in the community.

results.title: Our house
results.creator_credit: Meema Spadola, Sugar Pictures and Independent Television Service
results.brief_description: This US documentary profiles children in five diverse families as they face the challenges and joys of growing up in gay/lesbian households. An inspiring and warming exploration of what family values really should be about. The five families come from diverse socio-economic, racial and religious backgrounds across the USA.

results.title: Days of clear water
results.creator_credit: Emma Case, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Emma describes her life growing up with her nan, an independent lady who loved to tend to her garden and go for walks along the river. When her nan passed away, Emma lost not only her nan but her best friend.

results.title: Our Mutual friend
results.creator_credit: Julian Farino, Catherine Wearing and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Based on Charles Dickens last completed novel, this production paints a sweeping picture of London in the 19th century. With its themes of class war, sexual jealousy and overwhelming passion, it is a tale that is as relevant today as when Dickens first penned it.
results.description: Based on Charles Dickens last completed novel, this production paints a sweeping picture of London in the 19th century. With its themes of class war, sexual jealousy and overwhelming passion, it is a tale that is as relevant today as when Dickens first penned it.

results.title: Our land, our water
results.creator_credit: John King, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: A satirical presentation of the exploitation of resources of land, water and people, with the difficulties of satisfying conflicting needs. The responsibility to all users is raised, with the needs of the future in mind. Cast includes Stephen Tozer, Marjorie Brooke-White, Bob Walker, Allan Richards, Kenneth R. Hobman.

results.title: Days of reckoning
results.creator_credit: Ron Tanner, Lloyds Bank and Millbank Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Starting your own business”.
The third and final part of the series, Starting Your Own Business which traces the fortunes of three people starting their own businesses. Examines the only surviving member of the trio, an engineer whose business is in its third year. He is presented with the opportunity to expand and must reach a quick decision. Focuses on forward planning and monitoring performance.

results.title: Our children : Video package
results.creator_credit: Rachel Dixon, Film Victoria and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description: A Child Protection Package to train professionals who are in regular contact with children. Divided into 5 segments: 1: Defining abuse 2:Difficulties in reporting 3:Early detection and support 4:Networking for information exchange and case management 5:On-going responsibility for prevention, protection and support between family, CSV and professionals. Accompanied by 43p. Leader’s Guide including 8 overhead transparencies. The Leader’s Guide should be used in conjunction with the video. It gives background information as well as discussion questions and issues relevant to each segment.

results.title: Otway countdown
results.creator_credit: John Bird, Don Dennett and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A student production making a clear statement of the conservationists viewpoint of clearfelling and woodchopping of valuable native forests. It examines the history of the Otways and argues strongly against current practices. This film could be used in conjunction with films and resources giving the alternative viewpoints to stimulate debate on resource management.

results.title: Ottawa, today and tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Planning experts redesigning Ottawa consider its potentialities as a national capital. Animation shows how it began as a lumbering town at the junction of three rivers. Points out some of its undesirable features and shows the master plan embodying good town-planning principles and highlighting its scenic waterways, drives, and Houses of Parliament.
